problems.title: Maximum Neighborhood
problems.statementHtml:
Consider an n×nn×n grid filled with numbers as follows:

Let's define the cost of a cell as its value plus the sum of its neighboring cells' values. Two cells are considered neighboring if they share a side.

Your task is to calculate the maximum cost among all cells in the grid.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100) — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the maximum cost among all cells in the grid.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, there is only 11 cell with the cost 11.

In the second example, the cell with value 44 has the maximum cost: 4+2+3=94+2+3=9.

In the third example, the cell with value 88 has the maximum cost: 8+5+7+9=298+5+7+9=29.

In the fourth example, the cell with value 1515 has the maximum cost: 15+11+14+16=5615+11+14+16=56.

In the fifth example, the cell with value 1919 has the maximum cost: 19+14+18+20+24=9519+14+18+20+24=95.

problems.title: Addition on a Segment
problems.statementHtml:
You start with an integer array aa, which initially consists of nn zeros. You have to perform the following action exactly nn times:

You are given an array bb, consisting of nn integers. Your task is to choose such values ll and rr for each action that:

What's the maximum possible value of r−l+1r−l+1?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the length of the array bb.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers bibi (0≤bi≤n0≤bi≤n) — the elements of the array bb.

Additional constraints on the input:

  • there exists at least one way to choose ll and rr for each action and reorder the elements at the end so that aa becomes equal to bb;
  • the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the answer to the problem.
problems.noteHtml:
Consider the first test case. If the nn actions were as follows:

  • l=3l=3 and r=3r=3
  • l=1l=1 and r=3r=3
  • l=3l=3 and r=3r=3
  • l=3l=3 and r=3r=3
  • l=3l=3 and r=3r=3

The array a=[1,1,5,0,0]a=[1,1,5,0,0], so you can reorder the elements to make it equal to [0,5,1,0,1][0,5,1,0,1]. As can be seen in this case, the maximum value of r−l+1r−l+1 is 33. It can be shown that this is the optimal answer.

In the second test case:

  • l=1l=1 and r=3r=3
  • l=2l=2 and r=3r=3
  • l=3l=3 and r=3r=3

The answer is 33.

problems.title: Quotient and Remainder
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two integer arrays: q1,q2,…,qnq1,q2,…,qn and r1,r2,…,rnr1,r2,…,rn, as well as an integer kk.

You can perform the following operation any number of times (possibly zero):

Calculate the maximum number of operations that you can perform on the given arrays qq and rr.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105; 2≤k≤10182≤k≤1018) — the size of the arrays qq and rr and the upper limit for xx and yy.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers q1,q2,…,qnq1,q2,…,qn (1≤qi≤1091≤qi≤109) — the array qq.

The third line contains nn integers r1,r2,…,rnr1,r2,…,rn (1≤ri≤1091≤ri≤109) — the array rr.

Additional constraints on the input: the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print one integer — the maximum number of operations that you can perform on the given arrays.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, one operation can be performed: you can choose x=69x=69 and y=42y=42. Then ⌊6942⌋=1=q1⌊6942⌋=1=q1 and 69mod42=27=r169mod42=27=r1.

In the second test case, it is impossible to perform any operations, as suitable xx and yy cannot be found.

In the third test case, three operations can be performed:

  1. x=42x=42, y=17y=17: ⌊4217⌋=2=q3⌊4217⌋=2=q3 and 42mod17=8=r242mod17=8=r2;
  2. x=41x=41, y=16y=16: ⌊4116⌋=2=q4⌊4116⌋=2=q4 and 41mod16=9=r141mod16=9=r1;
  3. x=20x=20, y=12y=12: ⌊2012⌋=1=q5⌊2012⌋=1=q5 and 20mod12=8=r420mod12=8=r4;
After these operations, you'll get arrays q=[5,4]q=[5,4] and r=[9,100]r=[9,100], and there are no more operations you can perform.

problems.title: Almost Roman
problems.statementHtml:
Let's define a value of a string, consisting of letters "XVI", as follows:

You are given a string of characters "XVI?" and asked qq queries about it.

In the ii-th query, three integers are provided:

What is the minimum value of the string that can be obtained if all question marks are replaced with the letters 'X', 'V', 'I' so that the number of used letters does not exceed the number of available letters of each type?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and qq (1≤n,q≤3⋅1051≤n,q≤3⋅105) — the length of the string and the number of queries, respectively.

The second line contains a string consisting of nn characters 'X', 'V', 'I' and/or '?'.

The ii-th of the following qq lines contains three integers cX,cVcX,cV, and cIcI (0≤cX,cV,cI≤n0≤cX,cV,cI≤n) — the number of available letters 'X', 'V' and 'I' in the ii-th query.

Additional constraints on the input:

  • the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105;
  • the sum of qq over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105;
  • cX+cV+cIcX+cV+cI is greater than or equal to the number of '?' characters in the given string.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each query, print a single integer — the minimum value of the string that can be obtained by replacing all question marks with the available letters 'X', 'V', and/or 'I'.

problems.title: Binary Strings and Blocks
problems.statementHtml:
Define a block in a binary string (a string consisting of characters 0 and/or 1) as its continuous substring of characters of the same type that cannot be extended either to the left or to the right. For example, in the string 110001111, there are three blocks:

The substring from the 77-th character to the 99-th character 111 is not a block because it can be extended to the left. The substring from the 11-st character to the 55-th character 11000 is not a block because it contains characters of different types.

We call a string beautiful if we can remove exactly one block from it so that the resulting string consists of an odd number of blocks. For example:

You are given an integer nn and mm constraints, the ii-th of which is described by a pair of integers li,rili,ri. We denote the substring of the string ss from character ll to character rr inclusive as s[l:r]s[l:r], that is, s[l:r]=slsl+1…srs[l:r]=slsl+1…sr. Your task is to count the number of binary strings ss of length nn meeting the following condition:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test case.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (2≤n≤3⋅1052≤n≤3⋅105; 1≤m≤3⋅1051≤m≤3⋅105) — the required length of the string and the number of constraints, respectively.

Next, there are mm lines, the ii-th of which contains two integers li,rili,ri (1≤li<ri≤n1≤li<ri≤n) — the description of the ii-th constraint.

Additional constraints on the input:

  • The sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105;
  • The sum of mm across all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print one integer — the number of strings that satisfy the condition. Since it may be huge, output it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml: In the first example from the statement, the following strings are suitable: 1010, 0101. For each of these strings, both s[1:2]s[1:2], s[2:3]s[2:3], and s[3:4]s[3:4] are beautiful.

problems.title: Build XOR on a Segment
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array of nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an, where all numbers are from 11 to 212−1212−1.

You have to process qq queries. Each query is defined by three integers li,ri,xili,ri,xi: you need to find the smallest set S={s1,s2,…,sk}S={s1,s2,…,sk} that satisfies the following conditions:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer nn (2≤n≤1042≤n≤104).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤212−11≤ai≤212−1).

The third line contains one integer qq (1≤q≤1061≤q≤106).

Then qq lines follow. The ii-th of them contains three integers li,ri,xili,ri,xi (1≤li≤ri≤n1≤li≤ri≤n; 1≤xi≤212−11≤xi≤212−1).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each query, print one integer — the minimum size of the required set. If such a set does not exist, print 00.
problems.noteHtml:
Consider the queries from the example:

  • in the first query, you can choose S={5,4}S={5,4};
  • in the second query, you can choose S={1}S={1};
  • in the third query, you can choose S={4,3,5}S={4,3,5};
  • in the fourth query, you can choose S={1,3,7}S={1,3,7}.

tutorial.contentHtml:
2170A - Maximum Neighborhood

Idea: BledDest

Tutorial

2170A - Maximum Neighborhood

Because the matrix is small enough, you can iterate over each cell (i,j) and its neighbors: (i−1,j), (i+1,j), (i,j−1), and (i,j+1) (don't forget to check if these cells exists). This allows you to calculate the cost for each cell.

However, there are solutions which don't need to consider the whole matrix. We can show that the only four cells we have to consider are (n,n), (n−1,n), (n,n−1) and (n−1,n−1) — the two rightmost cells in the last two rows. For every other cell, the cost of the cell below it or to the right of it will be strictly greater. This allows us to check only four cells.

In fact, we can also show that for n≥5, the cell (n−1,n−1) is the optimal one, and its cost can be calculated using a simple formula. And the answers for n<5 are given in the problem statement.
